The '''MV ''Francop''''' is a German-owned, [[Antigua and Barbuda]]-flagged [[Merchant vessel|merchant]] [[cargo ship]]. In November 2009 the [[Israeli navy]] boarded the vessel in the [[Mediterranean Sea]], suspecting that it was carrying weapons destined for [[Hezbollah]] from the [[Islamic Republic of Iran]] in violation of [[United Nations Security Council Resolution 1701]]. Hundreds of tons of weapons were found on the ship, which was then directed to berth in Israel.
== Background == Built by Sietas of [[Neuenfelde]] and completed in August 2003, the ship was launched as ''Tavastland''.<ref name=Miramar>{{csr|register=MSI|id=9277412|accessdate=6 November 2009}}</ref> It measures {{convert|137.50|m|ftin}} long, with a beam of {{convert|21.30|m|ftin}} and a draught of {{convert|7.47|m|ftin}}. Its [[Maschinenbau Kiel|MaK 9 M 43]] [[diesel engine]] can reach a speed of {{convert|18.5|kn|km/h}}.<ref name=Poosu>{{cite web|url=http://www.poosu.net/2tavastland.html|title=M/S Tavastland |publisher=Poosu |accessdate=8 November 2009}}</ref> The ship has sailed under both the German and the British flags and is currently under the flag of [[Antigua and Barbuda]].<ref name="equasis">{{cite web |url=http://www.equasis.org/EquasisWeb/restricted/ShipInfo?fs=ShipHistory |title=Ship info: Francop |accessdate=4 November 2009 |date=14 April 2009 |publisher=Equasis}}</ref> It is currently owned by the German company Francop Schiffahrts GmbH & Co.<ref name=equasis/> A Cypriot company, United Feeder Services, operates the vessel.<ref name="BBC">{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/middle_east/8341737.stm |title=Israelis 'seize Iran arms ship' |publisher=[[BBC News]] |date=4 November 2009 |accessdate=4 November 2009}}</ref>
== Boarding incident == {{Main|Francop Affair}} On 4 November 2009, in an operation named [[Operation Four Species]],<ref>http://www.haaretz.com/hasen/spages/1126397.html</ref> [[Israeli navy]] [[commando]]s of [[Shayetet 13]] boarded the ship in the eastern [[Mediterranean Sea]] without resistance, acting on intelligence reports which it had received.<ref name="AP"/> The ship was about {{convert|160|km|nmi}} off the coast of [[Israel]], near [[Cyprus]].<ref name="BBC"/> A spokesperson for the [[Israel Defense Forces]] (IDF) said the ship was carrying "dozens of shipping containers, carrying numerous weapons, disguised as civilian cargo among hundreds of other containers on board". The IDF also claimed that the weapons originated from [[Iran]] and were to be directed to [[Hezbollah]].<ref name="BBC"/> The navy said that the crew was not aware of the purported smuggling and cooperated with Israeli commandos.<ref name="Haaretz"/> After the boarding, the Israeli Navy directed the ship to the Israeli [[port of Ashdod]], where a thorough inspection was held.<ref name="Haaretz"/>
According to the IDF, the ship picked up the cargo in [[Damietta]], [[Egypt]]; the cargo arrived in Egypt on a ship that sailed from [[Bandar-Abbas]], [[Iran]] on 25 October.<ref name="Haaretz">{{cite news |first=Anshel |last=Pfeffer |url=http://www.haaretz.com/hasen/spages/1126069.html |title=Israel seizes ship in Mediterranean carrying more than 3,000 rockets |work=[[Haaretz]] |date=4 November 2009 |accessdate=4 November 2009}}</ref> The ship was then set to sail to [[Limassol]], Cyprus and then [[Latakia]], Syria.<ref name="Haaretz"/> The IDF suspects that the cargo was intended for Hezbollah, which fought Israel in the [[2006 Lebanon War]]. Following the war, [[United Nations Security Council]] [[United Nations Security Council Resolution 1701|Resolution 1701]] forbade the shipments of arms to Hezbollah.
An Israeli naval official claimed that the amount of weapons found is ten times more than that found during [[Operation Noah's Ark]].<ref name="Ynet">{{cite news |first=Hanan |last=Greenberg |url=http://www.ynetnews.com/articles/0,7340,L-3800306,00.html |title=Navy: 10 times more arms on ship than on Karin-A |publisher=[[Ynet]] |date=4 November 2009 |accessdate=4 November 2009}}</ref> The arms shipment weighed 320 tons and were held in containers marked with Iranian shipping codes.<ref name="AP">{{cite news |first=Teibel |last=Amy |url=https://www.google.com/hostednews/ap/article/ALeqM5h3S0DqyLu9CfgcBASy2XHOGCk0IAD9BPAIG80 |title=Hezbollah denies link to arms ship |publisher=[[Google News]] |agency=[[Associated Press]] |date=5 November 2009 |accessdate=5 November 2009}}</ref><ref name=jpost>{{cite news | url=http://fr.jpost.com/servlet/Satellite?cid=1257455195197&pagename=JPost/JPArticle/ShowFull | title=The haul: 320 tons of Katyushas, other rockets, shells and bullets | last=Katz | first=Yaakov | date=5 November 2009 | work=[[The Jerusalem Post]] | publisher=jpost.com | accessdate=6 November 2009 }}{{dead link|date=January 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> The seized weaponry included 9,000 [[Mortar (weapon)|mortar shells]], thousands of 107-mm [[Katyusha rocket launcher|Katyusha rockets]], 600 122-mm rockets, and hundreds of thousands of rounds of ammunition.<ref name=jpost/> The arms shipment was the largest ever seized by Israeli authorities.<ref name="AP"/>
On 5 November 2009, ambassadors and diplomats from 44 countries and military attaches from 27 armies in the world were invited by the IDF and the Foreign Ministry in order for them to be witnesses of the many weapons and accumulation of ammunition that were found on the ''Francop'' ship.<ref name="IDF">{{cite news|url=http://dover.idf.il/IDF/English/News/today/09/11/0505.htm |title=Ambassadors, Military Attaches Witness Weapons Seized from Francop |publisher=[[Israel Defense Forces|IDF]] |date=5 November 2009 |accessdate=5 November 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110506234851/http://dover.idf.il/IDF/English/News/today/09/11/0505.htm |archivedate=6 May 2011 |df= }}</ref>

'''''Motor Trader Online''''' is the motoring guide in Malaysia published by PROTO Malaysia Sdn. Bhd.
Started by British entrepreneur [[Sir John Madejski]] in 1998, following the sale of his ''[[Auto Trader Group|Auto Trader]]'' [[classified advertising|classifieds]] magazine in the UK, Motor Trader magazine employs a similar layout to Auto Trader: cars are broken down into colour-coded sections according to car segments. In 2011, Sir John Madejski sold Motor Trader magazine and the company MTM Multimedia Sdn Bhd to Japanese conglomerate, PROTO Corporation.<ref name="proto-g">{{cite web|url=http://www.proto-g.co.jp/IR/english/news/release20110727.html|title=PROTO [IR Information] News Release|publisher=proto-g.co.jp|accessdate=2014-04-19}}</ref> The company MTM Multimedia Sdn Bhd became PROTO Malaysia Sdn Bhd in March 2012.
''Motor Trader Magazine'' won Advertising & Marketing's Motor Vehicle Magazine of the Year in 2011<ref name="adqrate">{{cite web|url=http://adqrate.com/magazine/details?id=91&type=2|title=Motor Trader | Magazine | adQrate Media Exchange|publisher=adqrate.com|accessdate=2014-04-19}}</ref> and 2013.<ref>Advertising + Marketing annual Magazine of the Year survey 2013</ref><ref name="lighthouse-media">{{cite web|url=http://lighthouse-media.com/OurProducts/Print/AdvertisingMarketingMalaysiaMagazine|title=Lighthouse Independent Media | Advertising + Marketing magazine (Malaysia)|publisher=lighthouse-media.com|accessdate=2014-04-19}}</ref>
''Motor Trader Magazine'''s website lists over 41,000 cars, updated in real time. Motor Trader Magazine and its website are viewed as "go-to" sources of information about cars, both new and used, in Malaysia.<ref name="expatgomalaysia">{{cite web|url=http://www.expatgomalaysia.com/article/1398/6-motoring-resources-in-malaysia|title=6 Motoring Resources in Malaysia - ExpatGoMalaysia.com|publisher=expatgomalaysia.com|accessdate=2014-04-19}}</ref><ref name="thestar">{{cite web|url=http://www.thestar.com.my/Business/Business-News/2013/11/30/Five-simple-ways-to-reduce-fuel-cost.aspx/|title=Five simple ways to reduce fuel cost - Business News | The Star Online|publisher=thestar.com.my|accessdate=2014-04-19}}</ref> Motor Trader website was described as "one of the most popular review and classified sites" in the automotive category in Malaysia by Marketing Magazine<ref name="marketingmagazine">{{cite web|url=http://www.marketingmagazine.com.my/index.php/categories/breaking-news/9872-malaysian-s-ignite-online-passion-for-car-culture|title=Malaysian's Ignite Online Passion For Car Culture|publisher=marketingmagazine.com.my|accessdate=2014-04-19}}</ref> based on the results of a study made by Effective Measure,<ref name="effectivemeasure">{{cite web|url=http://www.effectivemeasure.com/media/media-coverage|title=Media Coverage - Effective Measure|publisher=effectivemeasure.com|accessdate=2014-04-19}}</ref> the market research analysts for online media in September 2013.
Since 2012, ''Motor Trader'' has been the content provider for the Yahoo! Malaysia Autos page.<ref name="asiamediajournal">{{cite web|url=http://www.asiamediajournal.com/pressrelease.php?id=4553|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130215213445/http://www.asiamediajournal.com/pressrelease.php?id=4553|archive-date=2013-02-15|dead-url=yes|title=Asia Media Journal - Yahoo Malaysia Pens Content Deal With Motor Trader|accessdate=2014-04-19|df=}}</ref><ref name="yahoo">{{cite web|url=http://my.news.yahoo.com/autos/|title=Latest Autos News | Auto News Headlines – Yahoo Malaysia News|publisher=my.news.yahoo.com|accessdate=2014-04-19}}</ref>
In addition to ''Motor Trader Online (The Motoring Guide) and motortrader.com.my, there are also iOS<ref name="apple">{{cite web|url=https://itunes.apple.com/my/app/motor-trader-used-car-searching/id689171977?mt=8|title=Motor Trader: Used Car Searching Engine on the App Store on iTunes|publisher=itunes.apple.com|accessdate=2014-04-19}}</ref> and Android<ref name="google">{{cite web|url=https://play.google.com/store/apps/details?id=my.com.motortrader.main|title=Motor Trader (Official App) - Android Apps on Google Play|publisher=play.google.com|accessdate=2014-04-19}}</ref> mobile phone apps to enable car buyers to look up classifieds listings on their [[smartphone]]s and tablets. (UPDATED) Motor Trader app is no longer being supported. While there is no more app, Motor Trader Online is still fully accessible & responsive to all media devices.

'''Music in the Rockies''' was a week-long festival, with a combination of seminars, competitions, concerts, and events related to [[Contemporary Christian Music]], other kinds of Christian music, and the Christian music business industry. It has been replaced by a new event called [[Immerse]].<ref>[http://www.experienceimmerse.com Immerse Web link], Retrieved June 30, 2011</ref>
==History== The event started in 1975 as Seminar in the Rockies, launched by Christian Artists' Corp's president Cam Floria.<ref>{{cite web|title=Christian Artists Seminar Turns 25|url=http://www.todayschristianmusic.com/features/christian-artists-seminar-turns-25/|accessdate=7 May 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Artists Lineup Announced For GMA Music In The Rockies|url=http://breathecast.christianpost.com/Christian.Music.Artist-Artists.Lineup.Announced.For.GMA.Music.In.The.Rockies/Article-212_656.htm|accessdate=7 May 2013}}</ref><ref>[http://www.gospelmusic.org/newsmedia/pressRoom_detail.aspx?iid=14246&tid=33 It was Previously known as "Seminar in the Rockies"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120313112847/http://www.gospelmusic.org/newsmedia/pressRoom_detail.aspx?iid=14246&tid=33 |date=2012-03-13 }}, Retrieved June 30, 2011</ref>
In 2000, the [[Gospel Music Association]] (GMA) began to take over the event.<ref>{{cite web|title=Artists Lineup Announced For GMA Music In The Rockies|url=http://breathecast.christianpost.com/Christian.Music.Artist-Artists.Lineup.Announced.For.GMA.Music.In.The.Rockies/Article-212_656.htm|accessdate=7 May 2013}}</ref>
In 2004, they changed the event's name to GMA Music in the Rockies.<ref>{{cite web|title=Artists Lineup Announced For GMA Music In The Rockies|url=http://breathecast.christianpost.com/Christian.Music.Artist-Artists.Lineup.Announced.For.GMA.Music.In.The.Rockies/Article-212_656.htm|accessdate=7 May 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=CHRISTIAN/GOSPEL: MUSIC THAT CONNECTS|url=http://www.gospelmusic.org/wp-content/uploads/2012/11/GMA-Industry-Overview-2007.pdf|accessdate=7 May 2013}}</ref>
The event/festival was previously held at [[YMCA]] of the Rockies in [[Estes Park, Colorado|Estes Park]], [[Colorado]].
Both "Music in the Rockies" and "Seminar in the Rockies" had a series of concerts in the evenings, with some notable performers and attendees. The 34th annual event was held from August 3 to August 9, 2008.
In 2009, the event was replaced by a new event called [[Immerse]].<ref>[http://www.gospelmusic.org/newsmedia/pressRoom_detail.aspx?iid=41726&tid=33 Press release stating "... Immerse, a new event in Nashville to replace GMA Music in the Rockies"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120313112902/http://www.gospelmusic.org/newsmedia/pressRoom_detail.aspx?iid=41726&tid=33 |date=2012-03-13 }}, Retrieved June 30, 2011</ref>
Immerse is put on by the [[Gospel Music Association]] and [[LifeWay Christian Resources]].<ref>{{cite web|title=ABOUT » IMMERSE 2013 - Your Music Career Starts Here!|url=http://www.experienceimmerse.com/about/|accessdate=7 May 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Immerse 2013|url=http://www.lifeway.com/Event/worship-event-immerse-nashville-tn|accessdate=7 May 2013}}</ref>
Immerse features a series of seminars. It also has a competition section that is broken down into several categories, and an overall winner is determined. It is held in the [[United States]] in [[Nashville, Tennessee]].
==Winners== *2000 [[Foolish Things]] *1994 Terri Bocklund - "All Things" *1992 [[Point of Grace]] *1992 Janet Hawlik (comedy) *1980s [[Babbie Mason]]
==Notable performers and attendees== Numerous national recording artists have performed at, competed at, or attended the event.<ref>{{cite web|title=Estes Park - Feature Story|url=http://www.crosswalk.com/culture/music/estes-park-feature-story-540488.html|accessdate=7 May 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Christian Artists Seminar Turns 25|url=http://www.todayschristianmusic.com/features/christian-artists-seminar-turns-25/|accessdate=7 May 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Music in the Rockies - The Christian Alternative to "American Idol"|accessdate=7 May 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Jones|first=Kim|title=GMA's Music in the Rockies - Education and Competition|url=http://christianmusic.about.com/od/formusicministries/a/aaGMA30.htm|work=About.com Guide|accessdate=7 May 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Artists Lineup Announced For GMA Music In The Rockies|url=http://breathecast.christianpost.com/Christian.Music.Artist-Artists.Lineup.Announced.For.GMA.Music.In.The.Rockies/Article-212_656.htm|accessdate=7 May 2013}}</ref> <ref>[http://www.gibson.com/whatsnew/pressrelease/2004/aug6a.html Baldwin Celebrates Gospel Music Association's 30th Annual Music In The Rockies], August 6, 2004, Retrieved March 14, 2007</ref><ref>[http://www.gospelmusic.org/events/generic.aspx?aid=16&pid=132 Testimonials] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20061001034259/http://www.gospelmusic.org/events/generic.aspx?aid=16&pid=132 |date=2006-10-01 }}, Retrieved March 14, 2007</ref>

{{redirect|Orzeł}} {{DISPLAYTITLE:''Orzeł'' incident}} {{Infobox event |title=''Orzeł'' Incident |image=[[File:Orzel incident in Uus Eesti.jpg|300px|]] |caption=The ''Orzeł'' incident covered in the Estonian newspaper "''[[Uus Eesti]]''" (New Estonia). |date=18 September 1939 |place=[[Tallinn]], [[Estonia]] |cause=Polish submarine interned by neutral Estonia |result=Polish submarine escapes |casualties1=2 Estonian guards captured{{#tag:ref|The captured Estonian guards were later set free in [[Sweden]].|group=Note}} |casualties2=Submarine ''Orzeł'' damaged }}
The '''''Orzeł'' incident'''<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=kBzKB4ND38IC&pg=PA19&vq=Orzel&dq=Orzel&sig=2tm9LGdmIHMmWT7DM7XEA8pGxko His Majesty's Submarines; p 19;] {{ISBN|1-57638-021-1}}</ref> occurred at the beginning of [[World War II]]. The [[Poland|Polish]] submarine {{ORP|Orzeł|1938|6}} escaped from [[Tallinn]] in then-neutral [[Estonia]] to the [[United Kingdom]]. The [[Soviet Union]] used the incident as a pretext to justify the eventual [[Soviet occupation of the Baltic states (1940)|occupation]] of Estonia.
==Background== ''Orzeł'' was docked at [[Oksywie]] when [[Nazi Germany]] [[Invasion of Poland|attacked Poland]], setting off World War II. The submarine initially participated in [[Worek Plan|Operation Worek]], but withdrew from the Polish coast on 4 September as the situation evolved. Damaged by German minesweepers and leaking oil, the decision was made to head for Tallinn, which was reached on 14 September 1939 at about 01:30.<ref name= RKII>{{cite news |last=Kuzak |first=Rafal |date=31 October 2013 |title=Największy zdrajca z kampanii wrześniowej? Haniebna dezercja dowódcy ORP Orzeł |url=http://ciekawostkihistoryczne.pl/2013/10/31/najwiekszy-zdrajca-z-kampanii-wrzesniowej-haniebna-dezercja-dowodcy-orp-orzel/ |newspaper=ciekawostki historyczne |location= |access-date=20 February 2016 |language=Polish}}</ref> [[Lieutenant-Commander]] Henryk Kłoczkowski, the commanding officer, was taken to a hospital the next day for treatment of the unidentified illness he had been suffering from since 8 September.
The [[Hague Conventions (1899 and 1907)|Hague Convention of 1907]] enjoined signatories, including Germany, from interfering with the right of enemy warships to use neutral ports, within certain limits. Initially, the Estonians were quite accommodating of ''Orzel'', assisting with the repair of a damaged compressor.<ref name= RKII /> However, probably because of German pressure, Estonian military authorities soon boarded the ship, declared the crew interned, confiscated all the navigation aids and maps, and commenced dismantling all the armaments. An Estonian officer removed the naval ensign at the submarine's stern.<ref name= RK />
==The incident==
===Escape=== [[File:ORP Orzel.jpg|300px|right|thumb|ORP ''Orzeł'']] The crew of ORP ''Orzeł'' conspired to escape under the new command of its [[chief officer]], [[Lieutenant (navy)|Lt.]] [[Jan Grudzinski|Jan Grudziński]], and its new first officer, Lieutenant Andzej Piasecki.<ref name= HGH>Haar, Geirr H. [https://books.google.com/books?id=v8A7BAAAQBAJ&pg=PA52&lpg=PA52&dq=operation+worek&source=bl&ots=mqlUZZGdlu&sig=1dEMPn5xPUJglSWoywgGfRZ9wMs&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiWmvWTj4DLAhXFYiYKHUu0AdYQ6AEILjAD#v=onepage&q=operation%20worek&f=false The Gathering Storm] p. 53</ref> This started with Grudziński's sabotage of the torpedo hoist on 16 September, preventing the Estonians from removing the six aft torpedoes. Since it was a Sunday, another one couldn't be immediately acquired. Meanwhile, [[Boatswain]] Wladyslaw Narkiewicz took a small boat around the harbour. Under the guise of fishing, he covertly measured the depth of the planned escape route.<ref name= RK>{{cite news |last=Kuzak |first=Rafal |date=23 November 2013 |title=Orzeł wyzwolony. Brawurowa ucieczka z Tallina |url=http://ciekawostkihistoryczne.pl/2013/11/23/orzel-wyzwolony-brawurowa-ucieczka-z-tallina/ |newspaper=ciekawostki historyczne |location= |access-date=20 February 2016 |language=Polish}}</ref> Another sailor sabotaged the submarine's mooring lines.<ref name= little>{{cite book| last = Kelly| first = C. Brian| title = Best Little Stories from World War II: More Than 100 True Stories| publisher = Sourcebooks, Inc.| date = 1 November 2010| location =| pages = 21–24| isbn = 9781402243585}}</ref>
At around 00:00 on 18 September, the port lights suffered an unexplained malfunction. Seizing the opportunity, Lieutenant Grudziński prepared the submarine for departure. The crew was forced to delay by the arrival of an Estonian officer. After a 30-minute inspection, he deemed nothing to be out of the ordinary and bid the Poles goodnight. The crew resumed with their plans. Two Estonian guards at the dock were lured aboard and nonviolently taken prisoner, the lighting in the port was intentionally sabotaged, and the mooring lines were cut with an ax. Both engines were started, and the submarine made her escape in the darkness.<ref name= RK />
Estonian spotlights began sweeping the harbour, from the buildings to the quay, before finally locking onto ''Orzeł''. The Estonians opened up with machine guns and light artillery, damaging the conning tower. Heavier guns supposedly didn't open fire for fear of damaging other ships. At the mouth of the harbor the submarine briefly ran aground on a sandbar, but quickly managed to get free and escape into the [[Baltic Sea|Baltic]].<ref name= HGH />
===At sea=== Lieutenant Grudziński intended to seize the maps of a German vessel, as all of ''Orzeł''{{'}}s navigational aids, with the exception of a guide of Swedish lighthouses, had been confiscated. No German merchantmen were ever spotted, though. After three weeks of searching, it was decided to leave the Baltic and head for Britain. It took two days to pass through the heavily guarded entrance. The only references the Poles had were the lighthouse guide and a rudimentary map drawn by the navigation officer.<ref name=HGH />
The Estonian and German press covering the incident claimed that the two captured guards had been murdered by the Polish sailors. In reality they were deposited off of the [[Sweden|Swedish]] coast in a rubber dingy provided with clothing and food for their safe return home. The two guards were also provided with 50 [[US dollars]] each, as the Polish crew believed that those returning from the [[underworld]] "deserve to travel first class only."{{citation needed|date=February 2016}}
''Orzeł'' made landfall off of [[Scotland]] on 14 October. The crew sent out a signal in broken English, and a British [[destroyer]] came out and escorted them into port. ''Orzeł''{{'}}s arrival came a surprise to the [[Admiralty]], which had long presumed the submarine lost.<ref name= HGH />
==Aftermath== [[File:Orzel 1939 tablica tallin.jpg|100px|left|thumb|{{ORP|Orzeł|1938|6}} monument in [[Tallinn]], [[Estonia]]]] {{ORP|Orzeł|1938|6}} was subject to a refit and subsequently brought into service alongside the [[Royal Navy]] in the 2nd Submarine Flotilla in mid-January 1940 to patrol the [[North Sea]].<ref name= HGH /><ref>{{cite book|last=Haar|first=Geirr H|title=No Room for Mistakes: British and Allied Submarine Warfare 1939–1940|url=https://books.google.com.au/books?id=Hjk5CwAAQBAJ&pg=PA302|year=2015|publisher=Casemate Publishers|isbn=9781473875319|page=302}}</ref>
===Ramifications=== {{refimprove section|date=September 2016}} Following the event, the [[Telegraph Agency of the Soviet Union]] reported that the Estonian government had deliberately allowed ''Orzeł'' to escape and that other Polish submarines were hiding in ports throughout the Baltic states.<ref>{{cite book| last = Crowe| first = David| title = The Baltic states and the great powers: foreign relations, 1938–1940| publisher = Westview Press| edition = illustrated| date = 19 January 1993| pages = 88| url = https://books.google.com/books?id=LeFoAAAAMAAJ&dq=&focus=| isbn = 9780813304816}}</ref>
The Soviet Union, which [[Soviet invasion of Poland|invaded Poland]] on 17 September 1939, accused Estonia of conspiring with the Polish seamen and "aiding them to escape", challenging the neutrality of Estonia. The Soviets demanded to be allowed to establish military bases on Estonian soil, threatening war if Estonia did not comply. This was served as a political cover for their actions, as the [[Molotov-Ribbentrop Pact]] had already given German approval to the Soviet Union taking over the Baltic countries. The ''Orzeł'' incident was used to force a "pact of defence and mutual assistance" on Estonia, which was signed on 28 September 1939, and allowed for the occupation and annexation of Estonia by the Soviet Union in 1940.
''Orzeł'' sank no enemy vessels during her journey from Estonia to Britain, although Soviet authorities blamed her for the loss of the Soviet [[Tanker (ship)|tanker]] ''Metallist'' in [[Narva Bay]] on 26 September, the incident being used as a pretext for the [[Soviet occupation of the Baltic states (1940)]].

{{Infobox NRHP | name = Parker's Opera House | nrhp_type = indcp | nocat = yes | partof = [[Mason City Downtown Historic District]] | partof_refnum = 05000956 | image = ParkersOperHouse.jpg | caption = | location = 23 N. Federal Ave.
[[Mason City, Iowa]] | coordinates = {{coord|43|09|09.2|N|93|12|02.3|W|display=inline,title}} | locmapin = Iowa#USA | built = 1883 | builder = | architect = [[William Foster (Iowa architect)|William Foster]] | architecture = [[Victorian architecture|Late Victorian]] | added = November 20, 1998 | area = less than one acre | mpsub = | refnum = 98001325{{NRISref|version=2010a}} }} '''Parker's Opera House''', also known as '''Opera House Store''', '''Woolworth's''' and '''Parker Place''', is a historic building located in [[Mason City, Iowa]], United States. It was designed by the prominent [[Des Moines, Iowa|Des Moines]] architect [[William Foster (Iowa architect)|William Foster]]. Cousins H.G. and A.T. Parker built this structure as an opera house, which was the first one in the community.{{cite web|url={{NRHP url|id=97000392}}|title=Parker's Opera House|publisher=[[National Park Service]]|accessdate=2016-12-09|author=William C. Page}} with {{NRHP url|id=97000392|photos=y|title=photos}} While it initially filled a need in Mason City, it was replaced by more modern theatres around the turn of the 20th century. The third floor was created in the building in 1909 when it was placed across the middle of the auditorium. The first floor initially housed a clothing store, and [[F. W. Woolworth Company]] occupied it beginning in the mid-1920s, and the upper floors housed the local offices of the [[Standard Oil Company]] at the same time. The two-story addition in the rear was built in the 1960s. The first floor was redesigned in 1997 for Central Park Dentistry. The upper floors were converted into apartments in 2013.{{cite web|url=http://iagenweb.org/cerrogordo/history/MasonCity/cg_HIS_parkeroperahs.htm|title=Parker Opera House|publisher=Iowa GenWeb|accessdate=2016-12-09|author=}} Stone was used for both structural and decorative purposes. A metal [[cornice]] caps the main [[facade]]. The building was individually listed on the [[National Register of Historic Places]] in 1998, and as a [[contributing property]] in the [[Mason City Downtown Historic District]] in 2005.{{cite web|url={{NRHP url|id=98001325}}|title=Mason City Downtown Historic District|publisher=[[National Park Service]]|accessdate=2016-12-09|author1=Alexa McDowell|author2=Joanne R. Page}} with {{NRHP url|id=98001325|photos=y|title=photos}} ==References== {{reflist}} {{National Register of Historic Places}} {{NRHP in Cerro Gordo County, Iowa}} [[Category:Theatres completed in 1883]] [[Category:Apartment buildings in Mason City, Iowa]] [[Category:National Register of Historic Places in Mason City, Iowa]] [[Category:Victorian architecture in Iowa]] [[Category:Opera houses on the National Register of Historic Places in Iowa]] [[Category:Individually listed contributing properties to historic districts on the National Register in Iowa]] [[Category:Historic district contributing properties in Iowa]] {{Iowa-NRHP-stub}} {{Iowa-struct-stub}}

{{About|the Pets.com online company|the retail store company that currently owns the Pets.com domain name and hosts an online Pet Parent community|PetSmart}} {{Infobox company | name = Pets.com | logo = Petsdotcomlogo.png | traded_as = {{NASDAQ was|IPET}} | fate = Self-liquidated | successor = | foundation = {{start date and age|1998|11|}} | defunct = {{end date|2000|11|9}} | location = [[San Francisco]], California, United States<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/1100683/000089161800004394/e10-q.txt|title=FORM 10-Q|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=November 19, 2018}}</ref> | industry = | key_people = | products = | num_employees = 320 | parent = | subsid = | homepage = {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20000301100135/http://www.pets.com |date=March 1, 2000 |title=www.Pets.com }} }} '''Pets.com''' was a [[dot-com company|dot-com enterprise]] headquartered in [[San Francisco]] that sold pet supplies to retail customers. It began operations in November 1998 and liquidated in November 2000. A high-profile marketing campaign gave it a widely recognized public presence, including an appearance in the 1999 [[Macy's Thanksgiving Day Parade]] and an advertisement in the [[Super Bowl XXXIV|2000]] [[Super Bowl]]. Its popular [[sock puppet]] advertising mascot was interviewed by ''[[People (magazine)|People]]'' magazine and appeared on ''[[Good Morning America]]''.
Although sales rose dramatically due to the attention, the company was weak on fundamentals and lost money on most of its sales. Its high public profile during its brief existence made it one of the more noteworthy failures of the [[dot-com bubble]] in the 2000s.
==History== On November 21, 1994, the Pets.com domain name was registered by [[Pasadena, California|Pasadena]]-based Entrepreneur [[Greg McLemore]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://whois.domaintools.com/pets.com|title=Pets.com WHOIS, DNS, & Domain Info - DomainTools|website=whois.domaintools.com|language=en|access-date=2018-06-18}}</ref><ref name=":1">{{Cite book|title=Pets.com Inc.: The Rise and Decline of a Pet Supply Retailer|last=Merlo|first=Omar|publisher=Ivey Publishing|year=2009|isbn=|location=|pages=5}}</ref> The Pets.com website launched in early November 1998 as a spinoff of WebMagic<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.webmagic.com/yahoo-news/|title=Yahoo! News - WebMagic|date=1998-11-04|work=WebMagic|access-date=2018-06-18|language=en-US}}</ref><ref name=":2">{{Cite news|url=https://www.webmagic.com/yahoo-finance-3/|title=Yahoo! Finance - WebMagic|date=1999-03-29|work=WebMagic|access-date=2018-10-29|language=en-US}}</ref> and was incorporated In February 1999.<ref name=":1" /> After its start by Greg McLemore and [[Eva Woodsmall]], Pets.com was purchased in early 1999 by [[Julie Wainwright]].<ref name=":2" /><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.newsweek.com/amazons-pet-projects-167136|title=Amazon's Pet Projects|date=1999-06-20|work=Newsweek|access-date=2018-10-01|language=en}}</ref> [[Amazon.com]] was involved in Pets.com's [[Series A|first round]] of [[venture funding]], purchasing a majority 54% stake in the company.<ref name="amazon">{{cite web |url=http://phx.corporate-ir.net/phoenix.zhtml?c=97664&p=irol-newsArticle&ID=232871&highlight= |title=Amazon.com Announces Investment in Pets.com |publisher=Amazon.com |author= |date=March 29, 1999 |accessdate=February 14, 2014}}</ref> Amazon, along with [[Winblad Venture Partners]] and [[Bowman Capital Management]] invested $10.5 million into Pets.com in March 1999.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.marketwatch.com/story/sock-puppet-kills-petscom|title=Pets.com killed by sock puppet|last=Tarsala|first=Mike|work=MarketWatch|access-date=2018-06-22|language=en-US}}</ref> The CEO of Pets.com, Julie Wainwright, said of Amazon's investment, "This is a marriage made in heaven".<ref name="amazon" /> By October 2000, Amazon had a 30% stake in the company.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2000/11/08/business/technology-petscom-sock-puppet-s-home-will-close.html|title=TECHNOLOGY; Pets.com, Sock Puppet's Home, Will Close|last=Abelson|first=Reed|access-date=2018-06-12|language=en}}</ref> Pets.com spent most of the venture funding on large [[Warehouse|warehouses]] and other shipment infrastructures, as well as purchasing their biggest online competitor at the time, Petstore.com in June 2000 for $10.6 million.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.cnet.com/news/pets-com-to-buy-assets-of-rival-petstore-com/|title=Pets.com to buy assets of rival Petstore.com|date=2000-06-13|work=CNET|access-date=2018-06-06|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite book|title=How Venture Capital Works|last=K. Ryan|first=Peter|publisher=|year=|isbn=|location=|pages=}}</ref>
A regional advertising campaign using a variety of media began, which included [[television]], [[radio]], [[Print ad|print]], [[outdoor advertising]] and a Pets.com magazine, which had its first issue published in November 1999. The first issue was sent to 1 million pet owners in the [[United States]] during the month it was first published.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://multichannelmerchant.com/marketing/pets-com-publishes-print-magazine/|title=Pets.com publishes print magazine - Multichannel Merchant|date=2000-06-01|work=Multichannel Merchant|access-date=2018-09-28|language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://adage.com/article/news/pets-socks-competitors/1171/|title=Pets.com socks it to competitors|access-date=2018-09-28|language=en}}</ref><ref name=":0">{{Cite book|title=The Complete Internet Marketer|last=Neuman|first=Jay|publisher=|year=|isbn=|location=|pages=}}</ref><ref name=":3">{{Cite news|url=https://www.adweek.com/brand-marketing/iq-interactive-special-report-iq-qa-sock-dogma-40818/|title=IQ Interactive Special Report: IQ Q&A - Sock Dogma|access-date=2018-09-28|language=en-US}}</ref> Pets.com started with a five-city advertising campaign, which was expanded to 10 cities by Christmas 1999.{{Citation needed|date=October 2018}} The company succeeded wildly in making its mascot, the Pets.com sock puppet, well known.{{Citation needed|date=October 2018}} The Pets.com site design was extremely well-received, garnering several advertising awards.{{Citation needed|date=October 2018}} In January 2000, the company aired its first national commercial as a [[Super Bowl]] ad which cost the company $1.2 million.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070303063805/http://money.cnn.com/magazines/business2/business2_archive/2007/03/01/8401031/?postversion=2007022807|title=For startups, failure can be a good thing - March 1, 2007|date=2007-03-03|access-date=2018-10-29}}</ref> That ad was ranked #5 by ''[[USA Today]]'''s Ad Meter.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://admeter.usatoday.com/2015/01/21/best-super-bowl-commercials-2000-budweiser-mountain-dew/|title=Watch 5 of the best Super Bowl commercials from 2000|date=2015-01-21|work=Ad Meter|access-date=2018-07-21|language=en-US}}</ref> The company went public on the NASDAQ stock exchange in February 2000 and raised $82.5 million; the former Nasdaq stock symbol was IPET.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.cnet.com/news/pets-com-raises-82-5-million-in-ipo/|title=Pets.com raises $82.5 million in IPO|date=2000-02-10|work=CNET|access-date=2018-06-07|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite book|title=How Venture Capital Works|last=K. Ryan|first=Peter|publisher=|year=|isbn=|location=|pages=}}</ref>
Despite its success in building brand recognition, it was uncertain whether a substantial market niche existed for Pets.com.<ref name="cheyfitz">{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=mn_xucBVwzcC |title=Thinking Inside the Box: The 12 Timeless Rules for Managing a Successful Business |pages=30–32 |author=Kirk Cheyfitz |publisher=Simon & Schuster |year=2003 |accessdate=2009-04-22 | isbn=978-0-7432-3575-4}}</ref> No independent market research preceded the launch of Pets.com.<ref name="cheyfitz" /> During its first fiscal year (February to September 1999) Pets.com earned $619,000 in revenue, and spent $11.8 million on advertising.<ref name="cheyfitz" /> Pets.com lacked a workable business plan and lost money on nearly every sale because, even before the cost of advertising, it was selling merchandise for approximately one-third the price it paid to obtain the products.<ref name="cheyfitz" /> Pets.com tried to build a customer base by offering discounts and free shipping, but it was impossible to turn a profit while absorbing the costs of shipping for heavy bags of cat litter and cans of pet food within a business field whose conventional profit margins are only two to four percent.<ref name="cheyfitz" /><ref name="haig">{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=6o7SrLdgx8gC|title= Brand failures: The Truth about the 100 Biggest Branding Mistakes of All Time |pages=188–191 |author=Matt Haig |publisher=Kogan Page Publishers |year=2005|accessdate=2009-04-22 | isbn=978-0-7494-4433-4}}</ref> The company hoped to shift customers into higher-margin purchases, but customer purchasing patterns failed to change and during its second fiscal year the company continued to sell merchandise for approximately 27% less than cost, so the dramatic rise in sales during Pets.com's second fiscal year only hastened the firm's demise.<ref name="cheyfitz" />
In September 2000, Pets.com opened a new customer service call center in [[Greenwood, Indiana]] and relocated the majority of its customer work force to [[Indiana]] in order to cut costs.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20001102091508/https://www.cnet.com/news/0-1007-200-2717582.html|title=CNET.com - News - E-Business - Pets.com moves part of litter to Midwest|date=2000-11-02|access-date=2018-08-29}}</ref> They aggressively undertook actions to sell the company. [[PetSmart]] offered less than the net cash value of the company, and Pets.com's board turned down that offer (PetSmart would later buy a more successful version of Pets.com in 2017 called [[Chewy (company)|Chewy]]).{{Citation needed|date=October 2018}} The company announced on November 7, 2000<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://money.cnn.com/2000/11/07/technology/pets/|title=Pets.com goes out of business - Nov. 7, 2000|website=money.cnn.com|access-date=2018-07-26}}</ref> that they would cease taking orders on November 9, 2000 at 11am PST and laid off 255 of their 320 employees.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.msnbc.com/msnbc-originals/watch/the-pets-com-phenomenon-789155395746|title=The Pets.com Phenomenon|work=NBC News|access-date=2018-05-21|language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB973617475136917228|title=Pets.com Will Shut Down, Citing Insufficient Funding|last=Journal|first=Pui-Wing Tam and Mylene MangalindanStaff Reporters of The Wall Street|work=WSJ|access-date=2018-07-26|language=en-US}}</ref> Pets.com had around 570,000 customers before its shutdown.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.marketwatch.com/story/sock-puppet-kills-petscom|title=Pets.com killed by sock puppet|last=Tarsala|first=Mike|work=MarketWatch|access-date=2018-06-06|language=en-US}}</ref> Pets.com stock had fallen from its IPO price of $11 per share in February 2000<ref>[http://news.cnet.com/2100-1017-236799.html Pets.com raises $82.5 million in IPO]</ref> to $0.19 the day of its liquidation announcement. At its peak, the company had 320 employees,<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.msnbc.com/msnbc-originals/watch/the-pets-com-phenomenon-789155395746|title=The Pets.com Phenomenon|work=NBC News|access-date=2018-06-27|language=en-US}}</ref> of which 250 were employed in the warehouses across the United States. While the offer from PetSmart was declined, some assets of Pets.com, including its domains, trademarks and subsidiaries such as Flying Fish Express, were sold to PetSmart in December 2000.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.cnet.com/news/petsmart-com-snaps-up-rival-domain-name/|title=Petsmart.com snaps up rival domain name|date=2000-12-04|work=CNET|access-date=2018-06-18|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.zdnet.com/article/pets-com-sells-name-to-rival-petsmart/|title=Pets.com sells name to rival Petsmart {{!}} ZDNet|last=Grenier|first=Melinda|work=ZDNet|access-date=2018-09-30|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.ecommercetimes.com/story/5701.html|title=PetSmart.com Buys Pets.com Domain Name|access-date=2018-10-29|language=en}}</ref> As of 2018, the Pets.com domain redirects to PetSmart.com.
The Pets.com management stayed during the liquidation, which was finalized during a meeting on January 16, 2001 and [[CEO]] Julie Wainwright received $235,000 in severance on top of a $225,000 "retention payment" while overseeing the closure.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.computerworld.com/article/2589870/retail-it/pets-com-to-finalize-liquidation-plans.html|title=Pets.com to finalize liquidation plans|last=Mearian|first=Lucas|work=Computerworld|access-date=2018-07-18|language=en}}</ref>
=== Charity work === During the company's existence, Pets.com partnered with [[Best Friends Animal Sanctuary]] to start a [[Charity (practice)|charity]] called "Pets.commitment", which provided funding and support for [[Animal shelter|animal shelters]], [[Animal-assisted therapy|animal therapy]], [[service dog]] programs, [[pet care]] and [[Wellness Coaching|wellness organizations]]. The charity's motto was "people helping animals, animals helping people."<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20000529102043/http://www.pets.com:80/commitment/bestfriend_letter.html|title=Pets.commitment: Pets.com is partnering with Best Friends Animal Sanctuary|date=2000-05-29|access-date=2018-07-26}}</ref> After the Pets.com website closed in November 2000, Pets.com donated more than 21 tons of dog food to help [[Musher|Mushers]] in [[Alaska Interior|Alaska's Interior]] in December 2000.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.cbsnews.com/news/defunct-petscom-donates-dog-food/|title=Defunct Pets.com Donates Dog Food|access-date=2018-09-30|language=en}}</ref>
==Sock puppet== [[File:Pets.com sockpuppet.jpg|thumb|right|200px|The Pets.com sock puppet]]
Pets.com hired the [[San Francisco, California|San Francisco]] office of [[TBWA\Chiat\Day]] to design its advertising campaign. The firm had recently created the popular [[Taco Bell chihuahua]]. For Pets.com, they designed a doglike sock puppet that carried a microphone in its paw.<ref name="cheyfitz"/> The puppet, performed by [[Michael Ian Black]] (an alumnus of [[MTV]]'s surrealist comedy sketch show ''[[The State (1993 TV series)|The State]]''), was a simple [[sock puppet]] with button eyes, flailing arms, a watch for a collar, and a stick microphone emblazoned with "pets.com".<ref name="cheyfitz"/><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://cdnc.ucr.edu/cgi-bin/cdnc?a=d&d=OL20000127.2.39&srpos=1&e=-------en--20--1--txt-txIN-Pets.com-------1|title=Oak Leaf 27 January 2000 — California Digital Newspaper Collection|website=cdnc.ucr.edu|access-date=2018-06-12}}</ref> The sock puppet first appeared in Pets.com's advertising in August 1999.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://money.cnn.com/2000/11/07/technology/pets/|title=Pets.com goes out of business - Nov. 7, 2000|website=money.cnn.com|access-date=2018-06-22}}</ref>
As the puppet's fame grew through 1999 and 2000, it gained almost [[cult following|cult status]] and widespread popularity. The puppet made an appearance on ABC's ''[[Good Morning America]]'' and ''[[Nightline (US news program)|Nightline]]'', [[WABC-TV]]-produced ''[[Live with Kelly|Live with Regis and Kathie Lee]]'', was interviewed in ''People'' Magazine, ''[[Time (magazine)|Time]]'' Magazine, [[Entertainment Weekly]] and [[Adweek]] and even had a 36 foot tall "falloon" made in its image for the 1999 [[Macy's Thanksgiving Day Parade]].<ref name=":3" /><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2000/11/08/business/technology-petscom-sock-puppet-s-home-will-close.html|title=TECHNOLOGY; Pets.com, Sock Puppet's Home, Will Close|last=Abelson|first=Reed|access-date=2018-06-12|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2000/03/27/business/media-the-sock-puppet-that-roared-internet-synergy-or-a-conflict-of-interest.html|title=Media; The Sock Puppet That Roared: Internet Synergy or a Conflict of Interest?|last=Kaufman|first=Leslie|access-date=2018-06-15|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1999/11/24/nyregion/and-now-a-balloon-from-our-sponsor.html|title=And Now, a Balloon From Our Sponsor|last=Eaton|first=Leslie|access-date=2018-06-24|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite book|title=The Wisdom of Failure: How to Learn the Tough Leadership Lessons Without|last=G. Weinzimmer|first=Laurence|publisher=|year=|isbn=|location=|pages=}}</ref> In addition to the media appearances the Pets.com puppet made, merchandising was also done for the company including clothing, other trinkets, and a retail version of the sock puppet that delivered some of the puppet's famous lines, which started shipping on June 13, 2000.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://money.cnn.com/2000/11/07/technology/pets/|title=Pets.com goes out of business - Nov. 7, 2000|website=money.cnn.com|access-date=2018-06-03}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://slate.com/business/2000/06/the-puppet-that-ate-a-dot-com.html|title=The Puppet That Ate a Dot-Com|work=Slate Magazine|access-date=2018-10-29|language=en}}</ref> The Pets.com sock puppet toy was available until the website's shutdown.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://money.cnn.com/2000/11/07/technology/pets/|title=Pets.com goes out of business - Nov. 7, 2000|website=money.cnn.com|access-date=2018-06-03}}</ref> The Pets.com sock puppet also had an autobiography of himself titled ''"Me by Me",'' which was released in 2000''.''<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180628044126/http://www.businessinsider.com/people/pets-com-sock-puppet|title=Pets.com Sock Puppet - Business Insider|date=2018-06-28|access-date=2018-10-29}}</ref><ref>{{Cite book|url=https://trove.nla.gov.au/version/218941983|title=Me by me : the pets.com sock puppet book|last=Asen|first=Ben|date=2000|publisher=New York, NY : Ibooks : Distributed by Simon & Schuster|isbn=1588243702|language=English}}</ref>
After Pets.com liquidated, Hakan and Associates and [[BarNone|Bar None, Inc.]] purchased the rights to the puppet under a joint venture called Sock Puppet LLC for $125,000 in 2002.<ref name="cheyfitz" /><ref name="barnone">{{cite press release |title=Sock Puppet On Board With Bar None! |publisher=[[BarNone]] |date=2002-05-09 |url=http://www.barnone.com/sockpuppetrelease.htm |accessdate=2009-02-24 |quote=Bar None and Hakan Enterprises, Inc., joined forces to secure the rights for the Sock Puppet – and they are excited to be able to give him a “second chance” in the advertising world. |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20020602084525/http://www.barnone.com/sockpuppetrelease.htm |archivedate=June 2, 2002 |df= }}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://articles.latimes.com/2002/jun/24/business/fi-sock24|title=Sock Puppet Finds a New Home|last=WATERCUTTER|first=ANGELA|date=2002-06-24|work=Los Angeles Times|access-date=2018-06-18|language=en-US|issn=0458-3035}}</ref> Bar None, Inc., an American automotive loan firm, gave the puppet a new slogan: "Everyone deserves a second chance." and aired nine commercials featuring the puppet in July 2002.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://nypost.com/2002/06/19/2nd-act-for-pets-com-sock-puppet/|title=2ND ACT FOR PETS.COM SOCK PUPPET|date=2002-06-19|work=New York Post|access-date=2018-10-29|language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.chicagotribune.com/news/ct-xpm-2002-06-24-0206240006-story.html|title=Sock puppet gets 2nd chance|last=News|first=Joelle Tessler, San Jose Mercury|work=chicagotribune.com|access-date=2018-10-29|language=en-US}}</ref>
=== Lawsuit === As Pets.com's recognition began to grow, it attracted the attention of the creators of [[Triumph, the Insult Comic Dog]] and [[Ed the Sock]]. Representatives from [[Robert Smigel]] sent letters, including a [[cease and desist]] demand, to Pets.com claiming that the puppet was based on Triumph. Pets.com responded by suing Smigel in the [[U.S. District court|U.S. District Court]] in San Francisco in April 2000, demanding $20 million in damages for [[defamation]] and trade libel. But in revenge, on an episode of Saturday Night Live, Triumph humped the Pets.com dog in a bathroom.<ref>[http://www.thesmokinggun.com/file/dirty-sock-streisands-stocks Information on Smigel's lawsuit at] [[The Smoking Gun]]</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://dks.library.kent.edu/cgi-bin/kentstate?a=d&d=dks20000427-01.2.15&txq=Pets.com#|title=Daily Kent Stater 27 April 2000 — Kent State University|website=dks.library.kent.edu|access-date=2018-06-12}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://articles.latimes.com/2000/may/04/news/mn-26524/2|title=This Legal Dogfight Is No Joke|last=BROWNFIELD|first=PAUL|date=2000-05-04|work=Los Angeles Times|access-date=2018-07-26|language=en-US|issn=0458-3035}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://nypost.com/2000/04/26/pets-com-poop-on-conans-puppet/|title=PETS.COM POOP$ ON CONAN’S ‘PUP’PET|date=2000-04-26|work=New York Post|access-date=2018-08-11|language=en-US}}</ref> The lawsuit was dismissed in February 2001 by [[Judge]] [[Charles R. Breyer]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://ia802307.us.archive.org/34/items/gov.uscourts.cand.38967/gov.uscourts.cand.38967.docket.html|title=Case docket: Pets.com Inc v. Smigel|website=ia802307.us.archive.org|access-date=2018-08-10}}</ref>
== Legacy == The publicity surrounding the Pets.com puppet, combined with the company's collapse, made it such a symbol of dot-com folly that [[E-Trade]] referred to it in an advertisement during the [[2001 Super Bowl]]. The commercial, which parodies the famous [[Keep America Beautiful|crying Indian public service advertisement]] from 1971, shows a [[chimpanzee]] riding on horseback through a ruined dot-com landscape. The chimpanzee comes across a company named "eSocks.com" that is being demolished and weeps when a discarded sock puppet lands at his feet.<ref>[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ONZFkqzuMjI E-Trade Chimp on a Horse commercial, aired during the 2001 Super Bowl]</ref><ref name=":0" /><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.cnet.com/news/2hrs2go-etrade-wins-ad-super-bowl/|title=2HRS2GO: E*Trade wins ad Super Bowl|date=2001-02-22|work=CNET|access-date=2018-07-21|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://adage.com/videos/etrade-ghost-town/855|title=E-Trade - Ghost Town - Ad Age|website=adage.com|language=en|access-date=2018-10-29}}</ref>
In June 2008, CNET named Pets.com as one of the greatest dot-com disasters in history.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://crave.cnet.co.uk/0,39029477,49296926-8,00.htm|title=The greatest defunct Web sites and dotcom disasters|date=2008-06-05|publisher=CNET|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080607211851/http://crave.cnet.co.uk/0,39029477,49296926-8,00.htm <!-- Bot retrieved archive -->|archivedate=2008-06-07|accessdate=2008-06-05}}</ref>

[[World War II Victory Medal]] |family=Philip Corso Junior (son) |laterwork= |enteredservice= }} '''Philip James Corso''' (May 22, 1915 – July 16, 1998) was an American Army officer. He served in the [[United States Army]] from February 23, 1942, to March 1, 1963,{{cite web |last = |first = |authorlink = |coauthors = |title = Philip J. Corso's Department of the Army Form 66, Officer Qualification Record |work = |publisher = |date = |url = http://www.cufon.org/cufon/corso_da66.htm |doi = |accessdate = 2007-02-10}} and earned the rank of [[Lieutenant colonel (United States)|lieutenant colonel]]. Corso published ''[[The Day After Roswell]]'', about how he was involved in the research of extraterrestrial technology recovered from the 1947 [[Roswell UFO Incident]]. On July 23, 1997, he was a guest on the popular late night radio show, ''[[Coast to Coast AM]]'' with [[Art Bell]] where he spoke live about his Roswell story. This interview was rebroadcast by ''Coast to Coast AM'' on July 3, 2010. ==Biography== ===Military career=== After joining the Army in 1942, Corso served in [[United States Army Military Intelligence|Army Intelligence]] in Europe, becoming chief of the US [[Counterintelligence Corps (United States Army)|Counter Intelligence Corps]] in Rome. In 1945, Corso arranged for the safe passage of 10,000 Jewish [[World War II]] refugees out of [[Rome]] to the [[Mandatory Palestine|British Mandate of Palestine]]. He was the personal emissary to Giovanni Battista Montini at the Vatican, later [[Pope Paul VI]], during the period when the "[[Ratlines (World War II aftermath)|Nazi Rat Lines]]" were most active. During the [[Korean War]] (1950–1953), Corso performed intelligence duties under General [[Douglas MacArthur]] as Chief of the Special Projects branch of the Intelligence Division, Far East Command. One of his primary duties was to keep track of enemy [[prisoner of war]] (POW) camps in [[North Korea]].{{cite web|last=|first=|authorlink=|coauthors=|title=House Subcommittee on Military Personnel, Statement of Colonel {ret.} Phillip Corso|work=|publisher=|date=1996-09-17|url=http://www.aiipowmia.com/testimony/corso17.html|doi=|accessdate=2009-05-15|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080513101937/http://www.aiipowmia.com//testimony/corso17.html|archivedate=May 13, 2008|df=}} Corso was in charge of investigating the estimated number of U.S. and other [[United Nations]] POWs held at each camp and their treatment. At later hearings in 1992 of the [[Senate Select Committee on POW/MIA Affairs]], Corso provided first hand testimony, that many hundreds of American POWs were abandoned at these camps.{{cite web|last =|first =|authorlink =|coauthors =|title =Testimony Of Dolores Alfond Before The Pennsylvania Legislature|work =|publisher =|date =1999-05-03|url =http://www.nationalalliance.org/korea/k-alfond.htm|doi =|accessdate =2007-02-09|deadurl =yes|archiveurl =https://web.archive.org/web/20061211015741/http://www.nationalalliance.org/korea/k-alfond.htm|archivedate =2006-12-11|df =}}{{cite web |last = |first = |authorlink = |coauthors = |title = Senate Select Committee 49 |work = |publisher = AII POW-MIA |date = 1992-11-11 |url = http://aiipowmia.com/ssc/ssc49.html |doi = |accessdate = 2007-02-10 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20061103115429/http://www.aiipowmia.com/ssc/ssc49.html |archivedate = 2006-11-03}} At those hearings, Senator [[John McCain]] (R-AZ) dismissed the undocumented and uncorroborated allegations made by Corso as being extremely difficult to believe. McCain implied that Corso was guilty of fabricating the truth and essentially terminated the testimony being given by Corso immediately after a severe verbal reprimand on live television. McCain stated that his knowledge obtained from those who had personal relationships with Eisenhower led him to believe that Eisenhower was just not capable of allowing known American POWs to remain incarcerated after the termination of the Korean War. Corso was on the [[staff officer|staff]] of President [[Dwight D. Eisenhower|Eisenhower]]'s [[United States National Security Council|National Security Council]] for four years (1953–1957). In 1961, he became Chief of [[the Pentagon]]'s Foreign Technology desk in Army Research and Development, working under Lt. Gen. [[Arthur Trudeau]]. ===''The Day After Roswell''=== {{Main|The Day After Roswell}} [[File:Thedayafterroswell.jpg|thumb|left|120px]] In his book ''The Day After Roswell'' (co-author [[William J. Birnes]]) claims he stewarded extraterrestrial artifacts recovered from a crash near [[Roswell, New Mexico]], in 1947. Corso says a covert government group was assembled under the leadership of Adm. [[Roscoe H. Hillenkoetter]], the first [[director of Central Intelligence]] (see [[Majestic 12]]). Among its tasks was to collect all information on off-planet technology. The US administration simultaneously discounted the existence of flying saucers in the eyes of the public, Corso says. According to Corso, the [[reverse engineering]] of these artifacts indirectly led to the development of accelerated [[particle beam]] devices, [[fiber optics]], [[laser]]s, [[integrated circuit]] chips and [[Kevlar]] material. In the book, Corso claims the [[Strategic Defense Initiative]] (SDI), or "Star Wars", was meant to achieve the destructive capacity of electronic guidance systems in incoming enemy [[warhead]]s, as well as the disabling of enemy spacecraft, including those of extraterrestrial origin. ===Death=== Corso died of a "massive heart attack" on July 16th, 1998.http://www.phils.com.au/corso.htmhttp://www.v-j-enterprises.com/crsodies.html ==Gallery== ===Personal=== File:Philip_j_corso_2.jpg|In [[Rome]], 1945 File:Philip_j_corso_1.jpg|In [[Tokyo]], 1953 File:Philip_j_corso_3.jpg|In [[Germany]], 1960 ===Files=== File:Philip_j_corso_4.gif|DA Form 66 (page 1) File:Philip_j_corso_5.gif|DA Form 66 (page 2) File:Philip_j_corso_6.gif|DA Form 66 (page 3) File:Philip_j_corso_7.gif|DA Form 66 (page 4) File:Philip_j_corso_8.gif|DA Form 66 (page 5) His service number on his id card was 01047930 as shown on TV. ==See also== {{Portal|United States Army|World War II}} *[[Roswell UFO Incident]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ===Further reading=== {{Refbegin}} *{{cite news |last =W. {{italic title}} The '''''Reichskrieg''''' was a [[war]] fought in 1311 and 1312 by the [[Free imperial city|imperial cities]] of the [[Holy Roman Empire]] against [[Eberhard I, Count of Württemberg]], known as 'Eberhard the Illustrious Highness'.
== Course == Eberhard I supported the [[Bohemia]]n estates and the Bohemian king, [[Henry of Carinthia]] in their conflict against Emperor [[Albert I (HRR)|Albert I]] of [[Habsburg]] and his successor, [[Henry VII (HRR)|Henry VII]]. In 1309, charges were brought against Eberhard because of the grasping, self-serving way he discharged his duties as ''[[Vogt#Landvögte|Landvogt]]'', and he was therefore summoned by Henry VII to a ''[[Hoftag]]'' at [[Speyer]]. Eberhard left Speyer prematurely, whereupon Henry imposed the [[Imperial Ban]] on him. Henry now supported the [[Swabia]]n imperial cities in their confrontation with Count Eberhard of Württemberg, who had also operated an aggressive territorial policy against the cities. Because Henry was going to [[Italy]], he appointed the new ''Reichslandvogt'', Conrad IV of [[Weinsberg]], as the army commander of the Swabian imperial cities and several nobles. The principal Swabian cities involved were [[Esslingen am Neckar]] and [[Reutlingen]]; the nobles included von Tübingen, von Vaihingen and Herter of Dusslingen.
In spring 1311 the ''[[Reichskrieg]]'' began, the first military action presumably being the siege of enemy's family castle, [[Wirtemberg Castle|Wirtemberg]], which took place at the beginning of May. After a failed [[relief (military)|relief]] attempt on 26 May, the castle was captured on 13 July. After the [[Hohenasperg]] Castle fell in August 1312, Eberhard, now a fugitive, was received by his [[Margraviate of Baden|Baden]] brother-in-law, Margrave Rudolf Hesso in one of the two ''[[bergfried]]s'' of [[Besigheim]].
Only the death of Henry VII on 24 August 1313, and the political situation after the king's election in 1314, when [[Louis IV (HRR)|Louis IV]] was crowned king and [[Frederick the Fair]] was declared as [[counter-king]], prevented Württemberg's defeat. Eberhard then cleverly manoeuvered between king and counter-king, so that he was not only able to compensate himself for his territorial losses but also gain additional territories.
The Reichsheer captured or destroyed ''inter alia'' the following castles: Wirtemberg, [[Hohenasperg]], [[Hohenjungingen Castle|Hohenjungingen]], [[Ror Castle|Ror]], [[Old Lichtenstein Castle|Old Lichtenstein]], [[Haideck Castle|Haideck]], [[Hochbiedeck Castle|Hochbiedeck]], [[Greifenstein Castle (Württemberg)|Greifenstein]], Untergreifenstein,<ref name="Schedel">Hartmann Schedel: ''Weltchronik''. Reprint of [the] full coloured edition of 1493. Introduction and commentary by Stephan Füssel. Weltbild, Augsburg, 2004, {{ISBN|3-8289-0803-9}}</ref> [[Dischingen Castle|Dischingen]] near Stuttgart (thanks to coins discovered at the site by G. Weindefenung its destruction was dated to the early 14th century).<ref>{{cite web|title=Die „Räuberburg“ Dischingen … der Legende auf der Spur|trans-title=|periodical=feuerbach.de|publisher=|url=http://www.feuerbach.de/news_196_20051022435a88fb9e1af_.html|deadurl=yes|format=|accessdate=2012-01-11|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071209162650/http://feuerbach.de/news_196_20051022435a88fb9e1af_.html|archivedate=2007-12-09|last=|date=|year=|month=|day=|language=German|pages=|quote=}}</ref> and [[Marbach am Neckar]].
The following were not captured: [[Hohenneuffen]], [[Hohenurach]] and town, [[Hohenwittlingen Castle]] and [[Seeburg Castle (Bad Urach)|Seeburg]].<ref name="Schedel"/>
== References == <references />
== Literature == * Hans-Martin Maurer: ''Geschichte Württembergs in Bildern.'' Kohlhammer, Stuttgart, 1992, {{ISBN|3-17-010960-X}} * Theodor Schön: ''Schloß Wirtemberg in Blättern des Schwäbischen Albvereins''. 1897 * Erwin Haas: ''Die sieben württembergischen Landesfestungen''. {{ISBN|3-921638-59-3}} * Jürgen Meyer: ''Zerstört ward alles, stehen blieb kein Stein''. In: ''Im Schatten der Vergangenheit.'' Oertel + Spörer, 2004, {{ISBN|3-88627-270-2}}

{{Infobox Wrestling event |name = Rey de Reyes (2000) |image =AAAReydeReyes2000.jpg |caption=Official logo of the Rey de Reyes broadcast |promotion = [[Lucha Libre AAA World Wide|AAA]] |date = March 5, 2000<ref name="Rey2000">{{cite web|url=http://www.prowrestlinghistory.com/supercards/mexico/aaa/rey.html#2000|title=Asistencia Asesoria y Administracion Rey de Reyes|accessdate=February 19, 2009|date=March 5, 2000|publisher=Pro Wrestling History}}</ref> |venue = Toreo de Cuatro Caminos |city = [[Naucalpan]], [[Mexico State]], [[Mexico]]<ref name="Rey2000"/> |attendance =18,000<ref name=Canoe2000>{{cite web | url=http://www.canoe.ca/SlamWrestlingInternational/mexico_timeline-can.html | title=SLAM! Wrestling International -- 2000: The Year-In-Review Mexico | accessdate=July 31, 2015 | work=Slam Wrestling! | publisher=Canoe.ca}}</ref> |liveevent = Y |lastevent=[[Guerra de Titanes (1999)]] |nextevent = [[Triplemanía VIII]] |event=[[Rey de Reyes]] |lastevent2 = [[Rey de Reyes (1999)]] |nextevent2 =[[Rey de Reyes (2001)]] }} The '''Rey de Reyes 2000''' ([[Spanish language|Spanish]] for "King of Kings") was the fourth annual [[Rey de Reyes]] [[professional wrestling]] tournament and show, produced by the Mexican [[wrestling promotion]] [[Lucha Libre AAA World Wide|AAA]]. The event took place on March 5, 2000, in the Toreo de Cuatro Caminos arena in [[Naucalpan]], [[Mexico State]], [[Mexico]]. The Rey de Reyes tournament consisted of a semi-final round of four four-man elimination matches and a final match with the winners of each of the semi-finals facing off in an elimination match until only one man remained. The final of the 2000 Rey de Reyes tournament pitted [[Abismo Negro]], [[El Alebrije (wrestler)|El Alebrije]], [[Charly Manson]], and [[Cibernético]] against each other. Besides the five tournament matches the show featured an additional four matches including two ''[[Lucha de Apuestas]]'' matches, one where the hair of the wrestler's seconds were on the line. The other ''Apuesta'' match, which was also the main event match saw both [[La Parka, Jr.]] and Gigante Drako put their masks on the line.
==Production== ===Background=== Starting in 1997 and every year since then the Mexican ''[[Lucha Libre]]'', or [[professional wrestling]], [[wrestling promotion|company]] [[Lucha Libre AAA World Wide|AAA]] has held a [[Rey de Reyes]] (Spanish for "King of Kings') show in the spring. The 1997 version was held in February,<ref name="Rey1997">{{cite web | url = http://www.prowrestlinghistory.com/supercards/mexico/aaa/rey.html#1997 | title = Asistencia Asesoria y Administracion Rey de Reyes | accessdate = February 19, 2009 | date=February 21, 1997 | publisher= ProWrestlingHistory.com}}</ref> while all subsequent Rey de Reyes shows were held in March. As part of their annual Rey de Reyes event AAA holds the [[eponym]]ious Rey de Reyes tournament to determine that specific year's ''Rey''.<ref name=YIR1997>{{cite news|title=1997 Especial!|work=Box y Lucha Magazine|pages=2–28|id=issue 2332|date=January 7, 1998|language=Spanish}}</ref> Most years the show hosts both the qualifying round and the final match, but on occasion the qualifying matches have been held prior to the event as part of AAA's weekly television shows.<ref name=Lucha2004>{{cite news|title=Número Especial - Lo mejor de la lucha libre mexicana durante el 2004|work=SuperLuchas|id=Issue 91|date=January 24, 2005|language=Spanish}}</ref> The traditional format consists of four preliminary rounds, each a [[Professional wrestling match types#Basic elimination matches|Four-man elimination match]] with each of the four winners face off in the tournament finals, again under elimination rules.<ref name="Rey1997"/> There have been years where AAA has employed a different format to determine a winner.<ref name=Lucha2004/> The winner of the Rey de Reyes tournament is given a large ornamental sword to symbolize their victory, but is normally not guaranteed any other rewards for winning the tournament, although some years becoming the Rey de Reyes has earned the winner a match for the [[AAA Mega Championship]]. From 1999 through 2009 AAA also held an annual ''[[AAA Reina de Reinas Championship|Reina de Reinas]]'' ("Queen of Queens") tournament, but later turned that into an actual championship that could be defended at any point during the year, abandoning the annual tournament concept.<ref name=Reinas1999>{{Cite book | author=Royal Duncan and Gary Will | title=Wrestling Title Histories | publisher=Archeus Communications |chapter= Mexico: AAA Reina de Reinas | page= 400 | year= 2000 | isbn=0-9698161-5-4}}</ref><ref name=Reinas12>{{cite news | author = SuperLuchas staff | title = Lo Mejor de la Lucha Libre Mexicana 2008 | work =SuperLuchas | id = issue 296 | date = January 6, 2008 | url=http://superluchas.net/?p=11145 | accessdate = July 11, 2009| language = Spanish}}</ref><ref name=Reinas13>{{cite web | url= http://superluchas.net/2009/09/26/aaa-heroes-inmortales-homenaje-a-antonio-pena-resultados-en-vivo-26-septiembre-2009-%C2%BFque-pasara-con-la-lucha-entre-charly-manson-y-chessman-%C2%BFquien-sera-el-luchador-sorpresa/ | title= AAA- Héroes Inmortales III- (Resultados en vivo 26 septiembre 2009) – Cibernético gana el Trofeo Antonio Peña – Electroshock sustituye a Charly Manson contra Chessman – El luchador sorpresa fue Konan Big | author= Marquina, Alva | date= September 26, 2009 | accessdate= September 27, 2009 | publisher= ''SuperLuchas'' Magazine| language=Spanish}}</ref> The 2000 show was the fourth Rey de Reyes show in the series.
===Storylines=== The Rey de Reyes show featured nine [[Professional wrestling match types|professional wrestling matches]] with different wrestlers involved in pre-existing, scripted feuds, plots, and storylines. Wrestlers were portrayed as either [[Heel (professional wrestling)|heels]] (referred to as ''rudos'' in Mexico, those that portray the "bad guys") or [[Face (professional wrestling)|faces]] (''técnicos'' in Mexico, the "good guy" characters) as they followed a series of tension-building events, which culminated in a wrestling match or series of matches.
==Results== {{Pro Wrestling results table |hide=all |results=<ref name=Lucha2000>{{cite news|title=2000 Especial!|work=Box y Lucha Magazine|pages=2–28|id=issue 2488|date=January 9, 2001|language=Spanish}}</ref>

|match4=[[Charly Manson]] defeated [[Mascara Ságrada Jr.]], [[Histeria (wrestler)|Histeria]], and [[Dark Ozz|Path Finder]] |stip4=Rey de Reyes 2000 semi-final elimination match<ref name="Rey2000"/>

{{short description|annual theatre festival in Neuss, Germany}} '''Shakespeare Festival Neuss''' is an annual theatre festival in [[Neuss]], [[Germany]]. It has taken place in a replica of the [[Globe Theater]] on the grounds of the Neuss [[Horse racing|racecourse]] since 1991.
== Globe Neuss == [[Image: ShakespeareFestival Globe-Neuss.jpg | thumb|Globe Theater Neuss]] In 1988, a replica of the original London Globe Theater was built for the Landesgartenschau (''horticultural show of the state [[North Rhine-Westphalia|NRW]]'') in [[Rheda-Wiedenbrück]]. Reinhard Schiele, a theater-maker who, at the time, worked with the Schlosstheater [[Overhagen]], had the initial idea and supervised the entire project. Schiele wanted it to be as true as possible to the original, so he planned a mobile travelling theatre built entirely out of wood. This dream had to be abandoned due to [[fire protection|fire prevention regulations]]. The result was a [[dodecagon]]al theatre building made of a wood-and-steel construction that was no longer mobile. After the horticultural show ended, the theatre was not used for two years.
The city of Neuss and the ″Neusser Gemeinnützige Bauverein AG″ then acquired the building and rebuilt it on the grounds of the Neusser Galopprennbahn ([[Horse racing|racecourse]]) in 1991.
The multi-storey building, whose small windows are closed with black and white shutters, can accommodate about 500 spectators sitting on several levels. Not one seat is further than 10 meters apart from the stage. In the historical Globe Theatre there was virtually no seating at all but this would be unthinkable for today′s audiences.
== Festival == The festival has been held annually since 1991. In 2016 it lasted for about a month during June and July joining theatres around the world in celebration of the 400th anniversary of Shakespeare′s death. It is supervised by the cultural minister of the city of Neuss, as artistic director and production manager. The event is [[sponsor (commercial)|sponsor]]ed by a group called ''Friends of the Globe''.
The festival features an annually changing program of up to 30 performances attracting approximately 15,000 visitors. A space utilization of 90 percent is achieved.<ref name ="DRK2012a">[http://www.dradio.de/dlf/sendungen/kulturheute/1802969/ "'What else can you see in London and New Delhi?' Stefan Keim accounts for the Shakespeare Festival in Neuss], [[Deutschlandradio Kultur]] from 4 July 2012</ref> The mixture of national and international [[ensemble cast|ensembles]], the works of Shakespeare, partly in Original language, perform on the simple stage without elaborate backdrops, offers both faithful productions as well as contemporary arrangements and unconventional interpretations. The regular participants include the [[Bremen|Bremer]] Shakespeare Company and the [[Rheinisches Landestheater Neuss|Rheinische Landestheater Neuss]].
== Programme == [[Image: ShakespeareFestival CastleTheatreGyula.jpg | thumb | ''[[A Midsummer Night's Dream]]''. [[Hungary|Hungarian]] Burgtheater from [[Gyula, Hungary|Gyula]] in cooperation with the New Theater [[Budapest]] (2007)]] * 1991: Bremer Shakespeare Company: [[The Taming of the Shrew]], [[Antony and Cleopatra]], [[The Tempest]], and [[The Merry Wives of Windsor]] * 1992: first appearances of ''The Medieval Players [[London]]'', [[India]]n dance company Keli, the ''[[Rome|Roma]] Pralipe Theater'' and the Rheinische Landestheater Neuss * Since 1994, Patrick Spottiswoode has appeared on London's Shakespeare's Globe, which presents regular talks on "Shakespeare and the Globe" * In addition to frequently played pieces, lesser known works and modern arrangements were also added to the programme. In 1996 the "Théâtre le Ranelagh" from [[Paris]] presented an early Italian model for "Romeo and Juliet" in 15 [[pantomime]] clown pictures, while the "Nossa Cara" theater group from Brazil presented a "street hamlet" in 1995. * 2007: Semi-Operas of [[Henry Purcell]]: "The Tempest", "The Fairy Queen", and "King Arthur"; developed and performed by the Rheinische Landestheater in association with the Capella Piccola (a local choir specialised on [[Early Music]]) as well as the Metamorphosis ensemble and the academy for arts and media from Cologne * 2012: originally Afghan ''Theater Rah-e Sabz'' ("Path of Hope") performed a modern adaptation of the ''[[Comedy of Errors]]'' in context of a country devastated by decades of civil and religious war where the search for family members is no longer a mere act of comedy. The group had to relocate to India since their rehearsal room fell victim to a bomb attack. * also in 2012: Lithuanian director [[Oskaras Koršunovas]] introduced ''Miranda'', a most unusual adaptation of Shakespeare's 'Tempest'.<ref name="DRK2012a"/>
== External links == * [http://www.shakespeare-festival.de/ Website of the Shakespeare-Festival Neuss]
== References == <references />

[[Image:Shepherdsharvest.png|thumb|]] Minnesota's '''Shepherd's Harvest Festival''' is the largest [[sheep]] and [[wool]] festival in Minnesota.<ref>[http://www.shepherdsharvestfestival.org Shepherd's Harvest Festival Website]</ref>
==History== The festival began in 1997 and is run entirely by volunteers with support from the Minnesota Lamb and Wool Producers Association.<ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20020802222743/http://www.mlwp.org/calendar.htm Minnesota Lamb and Wool Producers]</ref> [[Llama]] Magic is held on the fairgrounds the same weekend as Shepherd's Harvest.<ref>[http://www.llamamagic.com/ Llama Magic]</ref>
It is held annually, normally each Mother's Day weekend at the [[Washington County, Minnesota|Washington County]] Fairgrounds in [[Lake Elmo, Minnesota]]. The official website lists the 2014 festival as the following weekend, May 16 - 18. <ref>{{cite news |author= |coauthors= |title=Getting fleeced |url=http://www.startribune.com/lifestyle/11491966.html |quote=A good resource for farms and shops is the Shepherd's Harvest Sheep and Wool Festival, held each Mother's Day weekend at the Washington County Fairgrounds in Lake Elmo. ... |work=[[Minneapolis Star Tribune]] |date=November 5, 2007 |accessdate=2010-06-02 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110607074627/http://www.startribune.com/lifestyle/11491966.html |archivedate=June 7, 2011 |df= }}</ref>
It has vendors selling a full spectrum of [[sheep]] and [[wool]] related items including fiber, yarns, spinning wheels, knitting supplies, sheep cheese, [[lanolin]], lamb burgers, vet supplies and breeding stock. It offers the only fleece competition in the state as well as hosting [[felting]], skein and photo competitions.<ref>[http://www.dl-online.com/articles/index.cfm?id=33890&section=news Detroit Lakes Tribune]{{dead link|date=May 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> Its educational component includes fiber related and sheep raising classes. Demonstrations include sheep shearing, dog herding, [[linen]]-making and a natural fibers fashion show. Local authors, sheep experts, [[knitting]] designers and chefs are invited to share their sheep and wool expertise with the community.

{{advert|date=October 2018}} '''SuperHappyDevHouse''' (aka '''SHDH''') is an international series of social events which organizers originally conceived as parties for hackers and thinkers. Founded May 29, 2005 by [[Jeff Lindsay (computer programmer)|Jeff Lindsay]] and [[David Weekly]] (founder of [[PBwiki]]), SHDH in [[Silicon Valley]] began by hosting 150 to 200 people every six weeks at rotating venues throughout [[San Francisco Bay]] and Silicon Valley, California. The unusual name derived from a popular 1991 ''[[Saturday Night Live]]'' satire, [[Happy Fun Ball]], which lampooned TV commercials and the [[NERF|NERF Ball]]. Weekly lived in a house nicknamed "SuperHappyFunHouse" after SNL's commercial parody, and that name was given yet another twist as SuperHappyDevHouse.<ref name=cheree/>
==Global expansion== By 2008, SHDH had expanded globally with CocoaDevHouse (London); SuperHappyDevClub (Cambridge, UK); Cologne DevHouse (Cologne, Germany); SuperHappyDevFlat (Zurich, Switzerland); SuperHappyHackerHouse (Vancouver, Canada); SuperHappyDevHouse Aotearoa (New Zealand); PhoenixDevHouse (Arizona); BostonDevHouse (Cambridge, Massachusetts); and DevHouse Pittsburgh (Pennsylvania).<ref name=cheree>Watkins, Cheree Renee. "What Is SuperHappyDevHouse? Party for Hackers and Thinkers Goes Global and Celebrates SHDH25," Suite 101, May 7, 2008.</ref> There was a DevHouse in Hermosillo, Mexico in September 2008, marking the first Latin American DevHouse, followed shortly thereafter by a Mexico City DevHouse on November 1, 2008, GuadalajaraDevHouse (Guadalajara, Mexico) on September 6, 2009 and 2 years later by a Dev House on Mérida, Mexico on February 28, 2010.
People, whether technical or creative, gather at a private home for not-so-serious productivity and socialization. Organizers say they're trying to "resurrect the spirit of the [[Homebrew Computer Club]]." It's a non-exclusive event intended for passionate and creative technical people that want to have some fun, learn new things, and meet new people. There is no admission charged; the event is paid for by donations and sponsorships.
The original SHDH was in [[Hillsborough, California]] and later in [[Los Gatos, California]].
As of August 2009, SHDH spawned [[HackerDojo]] to operate a [[Hackerspace]] in [[Mountain View, CA]] to allow for 24/7 programming, hackathons, classes, workshops, and lectures. SHDH now operates as an activity of Hacker Dojo Corporation.
